discussion.content: configure - build - sync

1. Configure properties
2. Synchronize DB
3. Build the solution

"Entities are created as views in Microsoft SQL Server, and staging tables are also added. Therefore, you must sync a database when(/ before/ as) you build entities."
I believe the correct order is Configure - Sync - Build.
Leaving the checkmark on sync when build means the system will sync before each build, leaving the order the same.
configure - build - sync
configure - build - sync

How answers in this paper are wrong? It should be Configure- build(check sync option to be true)- sync 

The answers this website giving is totally wrong.

Configure - Build - Sync
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/data-entities/build-consuming-data-entities

Correct one 
1. Configure properties
2. Synchronize DB
3. Build the solution
Explanation : Configure the data entity like key , name , fields then click right on project and sync db option (true) and last build the solution
configure - build - sync
why on Earth discussions have been deleted? damn

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
A company uses Dynamics 365 Finance.
Client companies require weekly updates for services performed. You create a custom data entity by using the Data Entity wizard.
You need to expose a list of services to external business companies.
Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Step 1: Synchronize the database
Entities are created as views in Microsoft SQL Server, and staging tables are also added. Therefore, you must sync a database when you build entities.

Step 2: Build the solution -

Build your project -
In Solution Explorer, right-click your project, and then click Properties.
Change the value of the Synchronize database on build property to True, and then click OK. This property must be set only one time per project.

On the Visual Studio toolbar, click Build > Build Solution to build the project.
Step 3: Configure properties for the data entity
After build visually validate and customize an entity
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/data-entities/build-consuming-data-entities

The import process is done through the Import tile in the Data Management workspace.

Import a data package -
1. Log into the environment using a login with sufficient privileges (typically this is the Administrator role).
2. On the dashboard, click the Data Management workspace.
3. Click the Import tile.
4. On the next page, do the following:
Provide a name.
In the Source Data Format field, select Package.
Click the Upload button and choose the appropriate package file from the location for the data being imported. This will import all the files from the package.
Click Save, and then click Import.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/data-entities/data-entities-data-packages
questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
A company is migrating from a legacy system to Dynamics 365 Finance.
You need to import the customer data by using the Data Management workspace.
In which order should you perform the actions? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Should be

Create a new import project
Specify the project category for the import
Specify the target entity
Specify the source data format
Import the source file to the project

comments.content: I dont know about 2 years ago, but now, if you dont select source data format, you dont have the option to select target entity.

discussion.content:
Latest version:

Create new import project
Specify the project category
Specify the source data format
Specify the target entity
Import the source file to project

4 5 2 1 3
You select source data format first and then specify target entity.

Correct one is 
Create a new import project
Specify the project category for the import
Specify the target entity
Specify the source data format
Import the source file to the project

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: custom service -
Custom service peak data volume is 1,000 records per hour.

Box 2: batch data API -
This scenario is best implemented by using batch data APIs, which has a peak data volume of 300,000 records per hour.

Box 3: OData endpoint -
Peak data volume for reading Odata status of orders is 5,000 records per hour.
This scenario is best implemented by using the OData service endpoints to read order status information.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/data-entities/integration-overview
questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
A company uses Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Management.
You need to integrate the system with third-party applications.
Which data integration strategies should you use? To answer, drag the appropriate data integration strategies to the correct scenarios. Each strategy may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Change place on first and last?

1. OData Endpoints
2. Batch Data API
3. Custom Service

comments.content: But needs a calculation so custom service.
These are not absolute peak numbers but given in a MS documentation as 'typical scenarios' for integration solutions. CS can handle much more than that and also faster than OData.
How is it possible? Custom service has peak of 1000 per hour and the 3rd case says 5000 per hour. I think the given answer is correct.
How the last one can be Custom Service? According to documentation Customer service can hold only 1,000 records maximum.

I agree. The last one is Custom Service.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/data-entities/integration-overview
I take it back. Sipa is correct

discussion.content: Dumb answer is correct
1&3 can be both Custom service or OData.

The answer is correct as the Odata endpoints can handle up to 5000 Records per hour while the custom service is only limited at 1000 records maximum and the batch data can handle at around 200,000 records at once. This can be seen from this link: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/data-entities/integration-overview#typical-scenarios-and-patterns-that-use-a-custom-service.

Can anyone explain to me what the difference between a custom service and just using Odata Endpoints are? Like looking at this https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/data-entities/integration-overview they shared same criteria for real-time data/peak volume/frequency for one case so how do you know which to use?

comments.content: I take it back. Sipa is correct.

discussion.content: Per the link https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/data-entities/integration-overview, the given answer looks correct.
correct

Custom service has peak of 1 000 pr. hour.
Batch data api has 200 000
Odata endpoints have peak off 1 000

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
A company plans to migrate purchase orders from an older system into Dynamics 365 Finance.
You need to generate field mapping between the source and the target data structures.
What should you do? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

Contoso, Ltd. uses Dynamics 365 Finance. You receive reports of performance issues with the app.
You need to use Performance Timer to investigate the issues.
Which URL should you use?

discussion.content:
Should be B 
"To open the Performance timer, open your webpage with the added parameter debug=develop: https://yoursite.cloud.test.dynamics.com/en/?cmp=USMF&debug=develop Note: When you run in debug mode you will notice slower performance. You can quickly get an overview of most performance issues by pressing F12 and working with the debugging tools that are available in your browser. The timer will show up here."

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/perf-test/performance-timer

Selected Answer: B
